Literature Review: The discovery of microRNAs (miRNAs) has revolutionized our understanding of gene regulation and cellular processes. These short, non-coding RNA molecules play crucial roles in various biological functions, including development, differentiation, and immune responses. In recent years, the field of virology has been significantly impacted by the revelation that viruses, particularly double-stranded DNA viruses, can encode their own miRNAs. This literature review focuses on virus-derived small RNAs (sRNAs) and miRNAs, their roles in health and disease, and the latest research approaches in this rapidly evolving field.Virus-encoded miRNAs (v-miRNAs) were first discovered in Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) in 2004 by Pfeffer et al. [1]. Since then, numerous studies have identified v-miRNAs in various virus families, with a particular prevalence in herpesviruses. These v-miRNAs have been shown to play critical roles in viral lifecycle, host-pathogen interactions, and disease progression.One of the primary functions of v-miRNAs is to modulate the host immune response. Cullen [2] demonstrated that v-miRNAs can target and downregulate host genes involved in innate and adaptive immunity, allowing viruses to evade detection and establish persistent infections. For instance, EBV-encoded miR-BART5 has been shown to target the pro-apoptotic host gene PUMA, promoting cell survival and viral persistence [3].The ability of v-miRNAs to regulate host gene expression extends beyond immune evasion. Kincaid and Sullivan [4] reviewed the diverse functions of v-miRNAs, including the regulation of viral gene expression, cell cycle control, and apoptosis. These multifaceted roles contribute to the establishment and maintenance of chronic latent infections, a hallmark of many DNA viruses.The impact of v-miRNAs on host physiology is not limited to acute infections. Emerging evidence suggests that v-miRNAs play significant roles in chronic stress, inflammation, and immunopathology. Boss et al. [5] demonstrated that persistent expression of v-miRNAs in latently infected cells can lead to long-term alterations in host gene expression, potentially contributing to the development of virus-associated malignancies.The study of v-miRNAs has been greatly facilitated by advances in bioinformatics and high-throughput sequencing technologies. Grundhoff and Sullivan [6] reviewed various computational approaches for predicting and functionally characterizing v-miRNAs. These in silico methods have become invaluable tools for researchers, allowing for rapid identification of potential v-miRNAs and their targets.One of the challenges in studying v-miRNAs is distinguishing them from host miRNAs and other small RNA species. To address this, Reese et al. [7] developed a novel bioinformatics pipeline specifically designed for the identification and characterization of viral small RNAs. This approach has led to the discovery of previously unrecognized v-miRNAs and other viral RNA types, expanding our understanding of the viral RNA repertoire.The potential therapeutic applications of v-miRNA research are particularly exciting. Zhu et al. [8] demonstrated that targeting specific v-miRNAs can inhibit viral replication and reduce pathogenesis in animal models. This approach opens up new avenues for antiviral therapy, potentially offering more specific and less toxic alternatives to traditional antiviral drugs.Furthermore, v-miRNAs have shown promise as biomarkers for viral infections and associated diseases. Kawano et al. [9] found that circulating levels of EBV-encoded miRNAs could serve as sensitive and specific markers for nasopharyngeal carcinoma, a cancer strongly associated with EBV infection.As our understanding of v-miRNAs grows, so does the need for comprehensive databases and resources. Kozomara et al. [10] described miRBase, a central repository for miRNA sequences and annotation, which now includes a substantial collection of v-miRNAs. Such resources are crucial for facilitating comparative studies and promoting standardization in the field.In conclusion, the study of virus-derived small RNAs and miRNAs has significantly enhanced our understanding of virus-host interactions and the molecular mechanisms underlying viral pathogenesis. As research in this field continues to advance, it promises to yield new insights into viral biology, host immune responses, and the development of novel therapeutic strategies. The integration of bioinformatics approaches with experimental validation will be crucial in unraveling the complex roles of v-miRNAs in health and disease.
